raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "Rectal suction biopsy", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This newborn presents with signs and symptoms consistent with Hirschsprung disease: delayed passage of meconium (>48 hours), chronic constipation, abdominal distension, poor feeding, and explosive stool following rectal exam. The physical features (low-set ears, flat nasal bridge, sandal gap) suggest Down syndrome, which is associated with Hirschsprung disease. The gold standard for confirming Hirschsprung disease is rectal suction biopsy, which demonstrates absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
